instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.D7701: What is D7701? diode in the backlight circuit sitting between the BKL_SW pin of the LED driver and backlight output. Very common for via between this and BKL_FB for feedback to blow, causing no boost. Measure continuity between pin 2 of this diode and feedback pin of LED driver if backlight output is PPBUS_G3H with no boost.
definitions.Q7706: What is Q7706? Q7706 takes PPBUS_G3H's main 12.6v and sends it through to the backlight circuit. If Q9706 is not allowing PPBUS_G3H through, you will get no voltage on the backlight circuit. Q7706 is a P channel MOSFET, meaning power will flow through it when the voltage on the gate is lower than on the source. Look at pin 3. R7788 takes the 12.6v that is on the source and places it right on pin 3. This will set Q7706 to "off", and not allow it to pass power, as the voltage on the source and the gate are identical..
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.LCDBKLT_BOOST: What is LCDBKLT_BOOST? LCDBKLT_BOOST is connected to the SWITCH(SW) pin of the LED driver and is switched to ground quickly after the inductor in the DC to DC boost circuit that boosts PPBUS_G3H to backlight voltage for the screen. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight/has image on screen
threads.message:
I have another MacBook Air 13” Mid-2013/Early-2014 <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B that I'm fighting with no backlight. Any help would be appreciated. I seemed to be getting quite a few of these lately.
No backlight on screen. Flashing question mark can be seen when illuminated from back of panel. All measurements are with known good LCD panel and taken when connected.

<CHIP>U7701</CHIP>
Pin 3=0v Diode mode measurement .579ohms
Pin 4=1.46v
Pin 5=0v
Pin 6=0v
Pin 16=5.13v
Pin 11=5.13v
Pin 14=3.32v


L7701 Pin 1=0v Pin 2=0v
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> Pin 1=0v Pin 2=0v
<CAPACITOR>C7704</CAPACITOR> Pin 1=1.46v
<RESISTOR>R7701</RESISTOR> Pin 1=1.46v
<RESISTOR>R7714</RESISTOR> Pin 1=0v
<RESISTOR>R7715</RESISTOR> Pin 1=0v
<RESISTOR>R7731</RESISTOR> Pin 1=0v
<CAPACITOR>C7711</CAPACITOR> Pin 1=3.32v
<RESISTOR>R7716</RESISTOR> Pin 1=0v
<CAPACITOR>C7710</CAPACITOR> Pin 1=5.13v
<CAPACITOR>C7714</CAPACITOR> Pin 1=5.13v
<RESISTOR>R7714</RESISTOR> Pin 1=0v
<RESISTOR>R7755</RESISTOR> Pin 1=0v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR> Pin 4=8.59v Pin 3=6.61v Pin 1,2,5,6=.34v Diode measurement .503 Ohms
<RESISTOR>R7788</RESISTOR> Pin 1=8.59v  Pin 2=6.61v
<CAPACITOR>C7782</CAPACITOR> Pin 1=8.59v Pin 2=6.61v
<RESISTOR>R7789</RESISTOR> Pin 1=6.61v Pin 2=5.91v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> Pin 3=5.91v  Pin 4=0v Pin 5=3.31v Pin 6=0v Pin 2=3.31v


XW7720 is not on board but is show in schematic

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight/has image on screen
threads.message: Bad <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>... Pins 2 and 5 have propper voltaje so both mosfets should be colse and you should have 0V on pin 3....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight/has image on screen
threads.message:
Thanks! I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> and now I have some different readings:

<CHIP>U7701</CHIP>
*After changing <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> Pin 3= .97v

L7701 *After changing <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> 8.53v both pins
<DIODE>D7701</DIODE> *After changing <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> 8.53v both pins

<TRANSISTOR>Q7706</TRANSISTOR>
after <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> change. Pin 1,2,5,6=8.58v Pin 4=8.58v Pin 3=2.62v

<TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR>
Changed out <TRANSISTOR>Q7707</TRANSISTOR> Pin 3=0v

Further down the rabbit hole! Ugh!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight/has image on screen
threads.message: so it is not boosting now, check feedback trace, voltaje on <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL>??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight/has image on screen
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight/has image on screen
threads.message: Looks like I have a short on pin 5 <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL> of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> as it leaves and goes to <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> in one of the layers of the board.  Should I try to dig out the connection from under pin 5 of <CHIP>U7701</CHIP> and then run a wire from there to <DIODE>D7701</DIODE>?  There's a componet labeled XW7720 on the schematic but it's not on the board so I can't jump it from there. Ideas?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight/has image on screen
threads.message: A short on <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL> would blow the fuse unless the trace from <DIODE>D7701</DIODE> to ball A5 is also corroded.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight/has image on screen
threads.message: I have a short to ground on both <SIGNAL>LCDBKLT_BOOST</SIGNAL> & <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_SW_LCDBKLT_FB</SIGNAL>.  I can find a place to make a jumper for BOOST but there's nowhere that I can see to make a jumper connection to the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> for the FB.  There's a TP shown on the Boardview but on the logic board it's not there.  Is it worth it to try to get a wire to A5 on the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> or should this go to the scrap heap? ugh!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B no backlight/has image on screen
threads.message: A5 ball you normally run a fine wire under the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> if the pad is totally gone, no other way. You can run a small piece of fine wire under it and then solder something larger to that and run that to the other side of the board.
